body: I'm going to close the PR since there is no activity for more than 1 month. But please feel free to re-open it and update with the master.

@lichen11 after `res <- rsvg(res, height = 5000)`, `res` is just a 3d array. The 3rd dim is the RGB value.

You can just rotate it and write it into a png file.
Sorry for this. I am refactoring the related functions. The related example and documents will be updated after that.
I'm going to close the PR since there is no activity for more than 2 months. But please feel free to re-open it and update with the master.
It's ready to merge.

the caffe converter is tested in the CI, but we only tried to convert a few commonly cnns, such as vgg/resnet. Each test is expensive. 

@arikpoz do you have a better idea how to test the converter?

given that there is already a resnet, i don't think an additional vgg will help too much. instead, i suggest to put vgg and others in a model package, so users can get it through `from foo.model import vgg`

The current test seems good to me, checking both performance and layer by layer outputs.

What takes times is the performance test since we run inference on many images.
To save time, we can remove the performance test, and trust that if the layer by layer outputs are close enough, then the end performance should be the same. 

The layer by layer test is done on a single image comparing all the outputs (and network parameters) of the caffe network and the mxnet network. Since we run inference on one image only, it is very fast to execute.

@mli will update following similar structure in image-classification. This was added because the fast-neural-style transfer example depended on VGG.

@mli @thirdwing having a prefix specific for R can help organizing the repo. Some repo (e.g apt) requires a specific file structure which doesn't apply to other repos (pip), though I'm not familiar with how CRAN is set up. Having a namespace can help avoiding mixing those repos, so I'd suggest having a key prefix such as `/R/`for your use for CRAN repo (e.g. https://s3.amazonaws.com/apache-mxnet/R/...).
No idea about pip. You can find cran folder structure from https://github.com/dmlc/drat

Besides, not only `img = cv2.imread(fullpath, args.color)`, but other-any-function calls about `cv2`, which results in this segmentation fault, such as fintuning or predict based on pretrained models according to official tutorials.

When I replace the `cv2` functions with `skimage` lib to load, resize images, it's okay. But, I have to admit, in fact, it's not a permanent solution. Because, in some situation, low-level call of MXNet will also occur this problem, I think it's about `opencv`, but not very sure.

After that, I use docker. In docker container, I make data preparing using `im2rec.py`, fine-tuning and prediction etc. It's okay and smoothly-used.

@eric-haibin-lin 
Benchmark for
`dot(csr.T, dns)=rsp`
**vs.**
`{dot(csr.T, dns)=dns2, cast_storage(dns2, storage_type='row_sparse')=rsp}`

Hardware: p2.xlarge
Device: cpu (4 omp threads)
Commit: [be009fe4c5a2a321aa92e99ac6e9cc511198c742](https://github.com/reminisce/mxnet/commit/be009fe4c5a2a321aa92e99ac6e9cc511198c742)
Compile flags: `USE_CUDA=0, USE_OPENMP=1, USE_BLAS=openblas`

| lhs shape | rhs shape | nnr | density | `dot(csr.T, dns)=rsp` (ms) | `dot(csr.T, dns)=dns2` (ms) | `cast_storage(dns2, 'row_sparse')=rsp` (ms)| sum of the previous two columns|
|:----------:|-----------|:--:|:--------:|:-----------------:|:---------------:|:--------------:|:--:|
| (512, 100,000) | (512, 100) | 40,004|        0.001 | 12.345  |         11.104 |    14.487 | 25.591 |
| (512, 100,000) | (512, 100) | 4,982|        0.0001 | 8.578  |         9.459 |    6.505 | 15.964 |

Script:
```python
import argparse

import mxnet as mx
from mxnet.test_utils import rand_ndarray, assert_almost_equal

parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="Benchmark cast_storage dns to rsp",
                                 formatter_class=argparse.ArgumentDefaultsHelpFormatter)
parser.add_argument('--m', type=int, default=512, help='num of rows of lhs')
parser.add_argument('--n', type=int, default=100, help='num of cols of rhs')
parser.add_argument('--k', type=int, default=100000, help='num of cols of lhs')
parser.add_argument('--density', type=float, default=0.0001, help='number of columns of the dense matrix')

args = parser.parse_args()

shape_lhs = (args.m, args.k)
shape_rhs = (args.m, args.n)
density = args.density

lhs = rand_ndarray(shape=shape_lhs, storage_type='csr', density=density)
rhs = rand_ndarray(shape=shape_rhs, storage_type='default')
out1 = mx.nd.dot(lhs, rhs, transpose_a=True, _out_stype='dns')
out1 = mx.nd.cast_storage(out1, storage_type='row_sparse')

out2 = mx.nd.dot(lhs, rhs, transpose_a=True, _out_stype='rsp')

assert_almost_equal(out1.asnumpy(), out2.asnumpy())
```
did you fix the bug you mentioned this afternoon? now dot(csr.T, rsp) = rsp is faster?

Yes, it was fixed [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/6842/commits/d58698461d95551006adef179dcbac5b76d38479).

I calculated the elapsing time of the whole function body for dot and cast_storage. Now the numbers do add up.
LGTM. I'll merge it.
good job !

No. 1
You used simple_bind, so all the ndarrays are initialized in backend as zeros. You can initialize those ndarrays before calling forward using the `arg_dict` interface of the executor `conv3D_ex`.

No. 2
Convolution takes two arguments when bias is off, `data` and `weight`. In order to use the imperative interface, you need to provide both. Consider the following:
```python
import mxnet as mx
a = mx.nd.arange(24).reshape((2,1,2,2,3))
weight = mx.nd.ones((2, 1, 2, 2, 3))
b = mx.nd.Convolution(data=a, weight=weight, kernel=(2, 2, 3), no_bias=True, pad=(1, 1, 1), num_filter=2)
print b.asnumpy()
```

The compiler raises error at link stage when ```lapack.so``` file exist at ```/usr/lib/lapack/lapack.so``` (the default ```lapack.so``` path in Debian 9) instead of ```/usr/lib/lapack.so```. I think the search path of ```lapack.so```should be localized by cmake instead of in the Makefile.

I found that by the official website of the course is especially difficult to install mxnet
Especially for the CentOS operating system. All procedures rely on too much.
The following is my time in the process of installing this example:

```
this is my stup steps about install mxnet in centos 6.4
#!/usr/bin/env bash

pre env
yum update
mkdir /home/dsg/software
cd /home/dsg/software
### download gcc g++ 4.8.5
wget http://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/gcc/gcc-4.8.5/gcc-4.8.5.tar.bz2
mkdir /usr/local/gcc
tar -jxvf gcc-4.8.5.tar.bz2 -C /usr/local/gcc
cd /usr/local/gcc
./contrib/download_prerequisites    

## wget http://www.mpfr.org/mpfr-2.4.2/$MPFR.tar.bz2 || exit 1
## wget http://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/gmp/$GMP.tar.bz2 || exit 1
## wget http://www.multiprecision.org/mpc/download/$MPC.tar.gz || exit 1

mkdir gcc-build-4.8.5
cd gcc-build-4.8.5
../configure -enable-checking=release -enable-languages=c,c++ -disable-multilib
make && make install

@asmushetzel what's your suggestion on mac? I've been maintaining pip prebuilt binaries, which is currently using openblas and it does have lapack, but due to its dependency on fortran compiler (not shipped with Xcode CLT), the build process has been very painful and unsuccessful. I've tried using gfortran from homebrew but it ended up with duplicate symbol conflicts that I can't resolve. Static linking is preferred, and dynamic linking should be limited to libraries that are shipped with the OS.
@wangmir are you using centos 7 too? Unfortunately, I don't have a box to test it on centos...
Shouldn't the macOS prebuilt binary be using Accelerate/vecLib by default?
nop, I'm using ubuntu 16.04 on TX1.
Is OpenBLAS's support for macOS good/mature?

The config we provide with MXNet for osx is based on accelerate framework and that has all lapack in there and works. If you instead use OpenBlas on mac, you  either have to go through the process of compiling the lapack libraries as well or switch off use of lapack in the config-file. (USE_LAPACK=0)

-import cv2

```

When you call mx.nd.array(x), if x is not a mxnet.ndarray or np.ndarray type, a numpy ndarray will be constructed out of x from np.array(x). In your case, neither x is a np.ndarray type, but in the first case, x is recognizable to np.array() interface, while the second one is not since it is a list of mxnet ndarray type.
@wangmir what's the output of `uname -a`?

It is all under the directory src/c_api, where c++ provides interfaces to be called from python. You can take a look at existing implementations such as symbol.py/executor.py to get a feeling of it. The convention of naming the interface has "MX" as prefix. So when you see something like _LIB.MXSymbolCopy, you can search for "MXSymbolCopy" under src/c_api to look at its c++ implementation.
